Award.AwardTitle: 2016 Frontiers in Particle Science & Technology Conference

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1623943
PI: Jaeger, Heinrich

This award will support participation of scientists and engineers at the American Institute of Chemical Engineers Particle Technology Forum, which will be held April 11-13, 2016 in Houston, TX. The goal of the forum is to enhance progress in understanding particle attrition, which refers to the wear and breakdown of particles in granular materials. The forum will focus on ways to mitigate particle attrition in bench-scale and commercial processes and on potential applications of attrition. The forum will have a balance of speakers from academia and industry and will be organized to promote connections between academic investigators and their industrial counterparts. Support will be provided to emerging scientists, including students, post-docs, and junior faculty, especially those from underrepresented groups, to help increase their participation.

Session topics will focus at the interface of research and industrial practice and will include particle attrition in industrial processes, improving models of particle attrition, breakages of agglomerates, attrition in pharmaceutical manufacturing, fundamentals of particle breakage mechanisms, and scale-up and industrial best practices. Results of the forum will help improve understanding of particle attrition, which will lead to greater process efficiencies, reduced costs, and to potential new applications of attrition. Encouraging the engagement of young investigators will fill a national need to continue to train the future work force in the science of particle technology and expose the next generation of researchers to the problems and questions that arise in this area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2016 Frontiers in Particle Science and Technology (FPST16) was held from April 11 – 13, 2016 at the Hilton Americas - Houston, in Houston, TX. It was organized jointly by the American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) and AIChE’s Particle Technology Forum (PTF). The conference was chaired by Ben Freireich, Research Scientist at The Dow Chemical Company and co-chaired by Ray Cocco, President of Particulate Solid Research, Inc. (PSRI).

The conference was organized by an interdisciplinary committee of academic and industrial researchers representing a wide range of interests with an underlying theme of particle attrition. This composition was chosen in order to ensure that invited participants were of a diverse scientific background and highly regarded by the scientific community for the quality and novelty of their current research. The Technical Advisory Committee ensured the success of the conference.

Meeting Program Chair:

Ben Freireich, Research Scientist, The Dow Chemical Company, USA

Meeting Program Co-Chair:

Ray Cocco, President, Particulate Solid Research, Inc., USA

Technical Advisory Committee:

Yeook Arrington, Particulate Solid Research, Inc., USA
Raj Davé, New Jersey Institute of Technology, USA
Karl Jacob, The Dow Chemical Company, USA
Heinrich Jaeger, University of Chicago, USA
Paul Mort, Procter & Gamble, USA

The 2016 Frontiers in Particle Science and Technology follows the success of a previous conference held at Hamburger University at McDonald’s Campus in Oak Brook, Illinois.

The 2016 conference brought together over 60 attendees, with international representation, who focus on the mitigation and application of particle attrition. The objective of the conference was to mirror the fundamental understanding of particle attrition mitigation and application with commercial needs, and to do so in an environment that promotes interaction among all participants. The attendees were leading practitioners and researchers in the field of particle technology, as well as young investigators including graduate students.

There were two keynote presentations (one from an academic participant and one from an industrial participant) and 22 oral presentations (divided into eight technical sessions) from speakers highly regarded by the particle community. The conference also featured a poster session and reception that allowed for the six graduate students and young researchers to present their research and network with leading researchers in particle technology on their first full day. Participation in the poster session was limited to a small number to encourage the attendees to visit all poster presenters during the reception. A variety of forums, such as breakfasts, lunches, and receptions were available for purposes of extended discussion and networking between participants.

Topics discussed included:

Breakage & Attrition Behavior of Agglomerates (Academic Keynote)
Problems, Solutions and Red Flags of Particle Attrition in Industry (Industrial Keynote)
Attrition & Breakage Fundamentals
Applications of the Fundamentals
Breakage Modeling
Breakup of Agglomerates
Case Studies
Testing & Measurements of Particle Attrition
